parts.text: Oh but my name is Unitarian Wagner and I am going to have a conversation with
Michael Levy for the oral history project. Visible lives. This
interview was recorded via phone on December fourth two thousand and
fourteen. And Michael
are where were you calling me from.
Mayor New York. I happened to be off from work today.
And right now I'm sitting in my room I was just holding my grandson and
he is somewhere else now and how do you get
involved with this whole project. I heard about it from the.
With Actually the N.F.B. Newsline had a section on the library
newsletter in the Andrew high school library and
this was on the newsletter so that was written about a month ago.
OK great I have a note here
that you wanted to talk a little bit about your childhood
. Yes I mean that's sort of where the instruction you know. So I'm
happy to do that.
Yeah well it's if you want to talk about
or where you grew up and OK I'll start from the beginning
I was born in Newark New Jersey on April fourteenth one thousand nine hundred fifty
two I was two and a half months premature
. The story then was that the
too much oxygen scarred the retina
and that resulted in virtual mental fiber pleasure and
total blind in two thousand. It I was
sitting in Jerusalem having breakfast with a major
ophthalmologist who worked under Dr Shepp and there's a
really major league guy in the field and he said no that wasn't it at
all it's now it's called R O P.
Something of prematurity In other words it with the retina itself that was growing
out of the way it should and the blood vessels burst and
scoring. So
that was kind of a since they had told the story hundreds of times already that what
it felt like having the rug pulled out from under my feet. But
that's just the beginning. My parents made up their minds pretty
quickly that they would treat me and if they treated my brother and sister
we moved to a place called Bradley Beach New Jersey which is where I grew up
it was a small resort town I grew up two blocks from
the ocean and have many fond memories of
what we used to call beach days. Some of which lasted till seven thirty in
the evening.
And just walking on the boardwalk they had a penny arcade
. We were always happy when the summer people left because
that left the place to us. I remember Hurricane Donna at
the age of ten my parents took me down to the Boardwalk.
Probably that night or the night after and I remembers what
happened was that the water came in under the boardwalk with such force that it
lifted the boardwalk up it hit a wall hit with to the boy
it couldn't go anywhere so it lifted the boardwalk up and I I still can picture the
boardwalk Slams and the bad shows got
completely washed away. These are all childhood memories.
The badge I was cut completely washed away there were a lot of wires hanging all around
. But mostly you know I was a small enough town that I could
explore which was a great thing that my parents let me do we have a your there was an
empty lot.
Now I'm going to have a rewind. First I got insurance when you
changed but your parents treated you like you made the decision to treat you like your brother and
sister.
What do you mean by that or what was the patient that
if they had sure as sure as they got to go to Coney
Island I went to Coney Island. They got money for their
piggy bank so I got money and they got disciplined and I got this. It's not that
my parents were terribly strict but you know there were rules
one of which was Don't wake your mother or your father if you
don't even go into the room if they're sleeping that was a that was a pretty From
won't. There was some clean up. Sure
this will show you how distantly in the past I was my job was to
take out the empty milk bottles and the glass empty milk bottles on many of them
for the milkman to pick up the next day.
So yeah I mean there were differences but I was when them within the range of you
know normal. We each had a seat that's where we sat for you know we always
them in the same place we were supper.
And when you know the everybody went to synagogue on Friday night and Saturday
so I guess that was it. You know they also looked at various states
and came to the conclusion that the New Jersey commission for the blind was a great
agency and therefore they stayed in New Jersey
Yeah interesting. So you just said you
were blind from birth
and you've always retained this shame out of sight but I have no
say at all I have that light perception possibly.
You know you get a lot of experiences from your siblings and from one
of the things that bothers me about today is that there are all these programs and
interventions when what I have
benefitted from most was an ordinary family and daily life
. My brother and I had a game where we would
I would stand on the back of his truck home and we would come
racing down a little hill and purposely fall off in the
grass. You know we did that endlessly.
No other such things. I remember I mean this is not unique
to blindness but we had cantons like back in the day of the Cold
War He was Fidel Castro when I was Khrushchev or he
was the Berlin Wall and I would try to get through you know this is what kids do this
is you know nowadays they talk about inclusion but really it
just mean the growing up with a family taking a risk if
you think there was a point at which you felt a separation
between you and your brothers and sister.
Absolutely. I have one brother and one sister. It was the day that I went
to Camp more so which was a camp for the moon's a sleepaway camp. I was
six years old my parents felt that I needed to learn certain
skills. I was terribly homesick but I wanted to be a good
boy so I went for four weeks which was a long time but
you know what nobody was how can I say.
Nobody was sophisticated in the fifty's in that way to say you know maybe you should
maybe you should only go for two weeks and that was kind of a defining
experience for me which I visit many
times even now. It's like a program running. Anytime I go
away from home those memories come back in one form or another
And what happened that I can't.
First of all I was exposed to a lot of other growing children. I had not
I only knew two other going children before that but more it was
like I had never been in a bunker I had never been with
swapped over with people my age and it was kind of well you know I had
been you know tranquil life and these guys were
yelling and stuff like that. So there was a kid it was
really homesick. They will. It's funny I went
to Israel last week and I brought back memories of like
a cascade of new events in other words new things to
be. I'm talking about you. The camp experience new things to be scared
of new things to do that I didn't necessarily want to do
. And just this feeling of
abandonment I would dream that I was in my house and then the
wake up bill would come and cut through the dreams and there I was a camp where I
didn't want to be. I went for ten years with
varying degrees of reluctance.
You know I tend to remember the negative experiences although I did
learn to swim. That was probably the most important thing
they tried to do table manners and stuff like that.
There was some music arts and crafts but mostly I remember
missing home.
Do you feel like you grew from an experience
that way.
Yes but.
The question I'm asking myself now is if you had been negative alway the
positive and it's I mean it's sort of a pointless question at this point
but I would have rather been sent to a sighted camp with
support I don't think my brother and sister who left home to sleep
away anywhere until you know they were maybe ten or
eleven.
Certainly not for four weeks.
Sure yeah. And do you feel like that that process of sort of being
thrown into something that you weren't ready for repeated itself after that camp
I think everybody creates their own worlds inside their heads
and I think that what they experienced didn't repeat itself in
the same way it came up. For instance when I
went to college and a trip that I would go on would
bring back memories of that. You know it's kind of like a computer trip it's kind
of burned you know the point that I
eventually came to cement on with that was then and now is now
you know took a war took a long time
. Sure.
So I'm wondering if you could tell me
a specific story from your childhood. Just
what I mean by that is you know if you're having a dinner party or something in a stripped down
and you and you want to tell an entertaining story to friends about your child
what story would you like to tell you Tony a story from one that comes to mind is.
My father especially loved jokes and you know having a good time
and so there was a guy who whenever he
got a little drunk he would lose sight. I believe it's a Rudyard Kipling called
Gunga Din about a hero of some war there was
a line you're a better man than I have been so my father worked with
my brother and I was weeks and weeks and weeks so that we could memorize that
poem and we cite it to this guy you know and kind of
left on their own in a funny way. So that was that was one story
that it didn't work.
I believe it I don't remember the reaction as
much as the preparation. I'll tell you another great story this is like the family
legends.
My.
My father's story where he had a clothing store a men's clothing store just he
and my uncle in Woodbridge New Jersey about a thirty five minute commute from
the house maybe forty five minutes and it burned down twice
. So one of those times it was a period where you really couldn't work I
couldn't do anything
. I mean I still I'll get to the story in a minute but I still remember
being in that empty store and smelling the smoke and my father was like
cleaning up and doing stuff and I was just with him all day it was kind of
an intimate experience. You know the radio is on
etc But here's the story so I they're going to go to Florida.
You know look we can't do anything here let's go to Florida. So they
had a combination of people taking care of us. My favorite and
my Uncle Harry and my Cousin Ellen and our babysitter was
that now became a professor later in life I always brag to
people about that. So. You know my uncle
and all were going to make marshmallows in the fireplace and when I do this and that and everything.
Well the minute they left like disaster started to happen
for us my brother got the chicken pox and I got the chicken pox when my sister got the chicken pox
in various degrees of severity. My parents called from
Florida. My brother said I got sick now and I'm going to be sick
until you come back so you better come back. Which if I were that
parent would have I would have been quite
startled and mortified but they stayed
and you know we survived I remember that neighbors
even showed up at our house that quarter
and in the morning and my aunt and uncle like didn't have a clue
why oh hello Stephen and then he just left it turned out that it was time to go
back to school after the winter vacation but you know but he had told them.
So there we were just kind of home I don't think we ever got to make the
marshmallows. But then a horrible and I'm
saying this in quotes a horrible incident almost
happened and that was that we were going to be visited by Dr Cannon who was a
lady doctor and the I.V. I must have been five or six years
old. The idea of being a fan by a lady doctor was terrifying to me
. I don't think she ever so showed up for.
That so that's that's the story I don't know what will care for you but you
know it to me a lady and doctor didn't go together you know we lived in our
enlightened times we don't want somebody looking at somebody you know
what do you imagine here it's maybe someone
beautiful or someone may be very ugly.
I imagine somebody of a different gender and I don't want them poking around you know
where I don't know I didn't get through the beautiful ugly porn I
just you know you know a guy is a guy
and you know you don't want to some lady looking at you it's like walking
into the girl's bathroom you know.
I mean you brought up beautiful and ugly I guess you have reasons for that
but I mostly
based puting on personality.
I love my Cousin Ellen very much because she always treated me very
well I don't know whether she was beautiful or not but I I thought of
her as beautiful.
You know I knew that my sister was considered
I don't know what the word would be.
You don't call a little girl beautiful may be cute
But I also loved her because she looked up to me you know and we
spent a lot a lot of time together.
So you know that that that certainly was a story shared
but there are lots of people in your life truly you should avoid you.
It's beautiful because of their personality who other people might have seen
in a different way or the other way around.
As a child I think I just related to the personality the idea
of good looking or not was not terribly important to me. You know
when I got to be a teenager maybe I began to hear more
about that.
But I mean my parents didn't put a big emphasis on it either. You know as long as
you were preventable that was then it was fine
. You know we're you know the it didn't go beyond that really
So you know I guess I guess that's what I would say about it.
Oh I. As I do today I had a
tremendous interest in the weather storms and snow in the
hurricanes and thunderstorms and you know I mean my kids
kid me about it today you know like you know did you check the temperature of what's going
on. But when I was seven a very big moment in my life
was that my. There was a meteorologist. I
don't know whether he had a degree or not but his name was Bill Martin and every morning at
seven thirty he would come on W J OK and give the weather you know and I
know that Bill Martin's coming on you know everything else has to stop. Now I have to
have you know Bill Martin whatever he's got to say so.
They took me to his weather station and
we talked about various things and the next day on the radio he said Oh I
had a visitor. You know my name you know mention my name
you know and it was such a small town area that you could
call the radio station and get somebodies birthday announced on the
radio and you get two tickets to Walter Reed you know it was it
was very out of towners and I
really enjoyed that tremendously.
What was it about the weather that you enjoyed so much.
Well here's the funny thing you don't when you enjoy something you don't analyze it
you just enjoy it but I think it was the there was a certain drama you know they were
quail and there were storms there was rain and there was high pressure and there was low pressure
you know I live near the ocean. I knew all about what
I could. I knew that my father although he
didn't teach me to swim technically we spent a lot of time in the water and I knew if a big
